summary.p: [1] Just yesterday, Blarer wrote [not received]. Now he learns through a letter written by a man in Nuremberg on June 14th that Emperor Charles V has sent troops and 1500 horsemen to Duke Eric of Brunswick-Calenberg, all of whom were then killed by Wilhelm von Thumshirn. This will cause the Emperor great concern!
[2] In Ulm, the [Imperial Estates] are gathered to form a new [Swabian] League.

[3] Bullinger should give the enclosed letter to Hans Schöner and also advance him money if needed. Blarer is expecting a money transfer for Schöner, which he will send to him with the first secure messenger.

[5] [P.S.:] Blarer hereby recommends Marcell Dietrich von Schankwitz, who is looking forward to meeting Bullinger. He and his pious wife [Anna, née Zehntmeier] (both very amiable people) are recommended to Bullinger.

div.p: Dear sir and brother. I wrote to you yesterday. Now further news comes from Nuremberg from an honest man (the letter is dated Nuremberg, June 14th), that the Emperor has sent 1500 horsemen along with several mercenaries to Duke Eric of Brunswick, to assist him, but they arrived too late and were all killed by Wilhelm von Thumshirn. It is believed that this will cause the Emperor much trouble.
In Ulm, people are now gathered to establish a new league.

To respond to the good Schöner's enclosed letter without delay, and also to advance him money if he needs it. I am expecting to receive money on his behalf any day now. I will send it to him with the first secure messenger.
Praying to God earnestly, earnestly, earnestly for us. Greet everyone. Dated June 22nd. A. Bl.
I commend to you with great desire to see you, our dear Marcellus, along with his most pious wife. They are truly people worthy of being loved by all good men.
To the most excellent man, Heinrich Bullinger, his friend as if his brother, by far the dearest of all.
